narrative=Arthur Smith, known for his community involvement, was last seen attending an outdoor festival near a prominent religious site, known for volunteer work in Edinburgh, possibly at the address of 1 St James Square, EH1 3AX. According to his friend, Jennifer, Arthur exhibited personality changes shortly before his disappearance. His sister, Francesca Ahmed, noticed Arthur seemed unusually withdrawn during recent grandchild's school events. After the festival, Arthur failed to return home, prompting concern among his friends. He was eventually found safe by a member of the public at 16 Bernard Terrace and was returned home. Arthur's temporary absence remains a mystery but is believed to be linked to the recent stressors.

narrative=Arthur Smith, who lived in a converted van, had exhibited noticeable personality changes in the days before his disappearance. Amanda Anderson, a close acquaintance, noted these shifts but did not suspect an impending absence. Arthur was last seen at a religious site near 55 Eastfield, Edinburgh, following an outdoor festival where he reportedly appeared disoriented. The festival and the religious site held significance for him, possibly influencing his decision to linger there. As days passed without contact, concerns grew. Arthur was eventually traced by police to 69-71 Whitehill Street, Musselburgh, confirming his safety. His absence, though concerning, was resolved without incident.

narrative=Arthur Smith was last seen leaving 1G Bank Street, his residence in North Berwick. He informed his sister, Susan Smith, that he intended to visit the medical clinic at 23a Rosebery Avenue, South Queensferry. Arthur, who has a disability, was expected to return home within a few hours but failed to do so. Concerned, Susan contacted his friend, Tracey Holland, who confirmed that Arthur had not attended his scheduled appointment. Initially seen as low risk due to prior punctuality on similar outings, Arthur's absence stretched over several days. Eventually, police located him at 6 Goldeneye Gait in Edinburgh. Keeping his safety in mind, they arranged his return home without incident.

narrative=Arthur Smith was reported missing after failing to return home from an afternoon outing. Although unharmed, he seemed disoriented and was safely escorted home by authorities.

When Arthur failed to return home and was unresponsive to calls, his friends grew increasingly worried, prompting them to contact authorities, leading to a thorough search effort in the vicinity. narrative=Arthur Smith, a 75-year-old male from Aberdeen, was reported missing after a series of noticeable changes in his behavior. His sister, Hilary Mason, mentioned that Arthur, who had been living in a converted van parked outside 8 East Mains Holdings, Newbridge, had become increasingly withdrawn and irritable. Before his disappearance, Arthur had visited a close friend at 5 Almond Avenue, Edinburgh, where he voiced concerns that seemed out of character for him. Despite his low initial risk assessment, Arthur’s prolonged absence raised concerns among his family and friends. He was eventually located by the police at 6 Goldeneye Gait, exhibiting signs of disorientation but otherwise safe. The circumstances suggested that Arthur's sudden withdrawal and change in personality may have contributed to his disappearance.
